Marie Curie: Marie Curie was a pioneering physicist and chemist who made groundbreaking discoveries in radioactivity and won two Nobel Prizes. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the first person to win two Nobel Prizes in different fields. Bringing her back to life would allow us to continue her research and potentially lead to new breakthroughs in the fields of physics and chemistry. Her contributions to science have had a lasting impact on our understanding of the world, and her presence today could inspire a new generation of scientists and explorers.

Mahatma Gandhi: Mahatma Gandhi was a leader of India's independence movement against British rule. He was known for his non-violent protests and his philosophy of non-violence. Bringing him back to life would allow us to continue his work towards peaceful resolution of conflicts and the promotion of non-violence as a means of achieving social and political change. His philosophy has had a lasting impact on civil rights movements around the world, and his presence today could inspire a new generation of peaceful activists.
Albert Einstein: Albert Einstein was a brilliant physicist and mathematician who developed the theory of relativity and the famous equation E=mc^

He was also a passionate advocate for peace and human rights. Bringing him back to life would allow us to continue his work in physics and potentially lead to new breakthroughs in the field. His contributions to science have had a lasting impact on our understanding of the universe, and his presence today could inspire a new generation of scientists and explorers.

Rosa Parks: Rosa Parks was a civil rights activist who became famous for her role in the Montgomery Bus Boycott. She was arrested for refusing to give up her seat on a bus to a white person, which sparked the civil rights movement in the United States. Bringing her back to life would allow us to continue her work towards racial equality and justice. Her courage and determination have had a lasting impact on the civil rights movement, and her presence today could inspire a new generation of activists.
